What book is The movie Arch of Triumph based on?

The movieArch of Triumph is based on the bookArch of Triumphwritten by  Erich Maria Remarque , Walter Sorell and Denver Lindley

Arch of TriumphPublished by Simon Publications - 12/1/1945

Written with wisdom, compassion & humor, the author of "All Quiet on the Western Front" vividly describes the life of white Russian refugees on the periphery of the decadent high society in Paris between the two World Wars, on the brink of catastrophe.

Related books / From the author(s)

Arch of Triumph

written byErich Maria Remarque, Walter SorellandDenver Lindley

Published by Simon Publications - 12/1/1945

Written with wisdom, compassion & humor, the author of "All Quiet on the Western Front" vividly describes the life of white Russian refugees on the periphery of the decadent high society in Paris between the two World Wars, on the brink of catastrophe.

Arch of Triumph

written byErich Maria Remarque

Published by Random House - 2/4/2014

The evocative story of a man without a country, Arch of Triumph is a World War II–era classic from the author of All Quiet on the Western Front. It is 1939. Despite a law banning him from performing surgery, Ravic—a German doctor and refugee living in Paris—has been treating some of the city’s most elite citizens for two years on the behalf of two less-than-skillful French physicians. Forbidden to return to his own country, and dodging the everyday dangers of jail and deportation, Ravic manages to hang on—all the while searching for the Nazi who tortured him back in Germany. And though he’s given up on the possibility of love, life has a curious way of taking a turn for the romantic, even during the worst of times. “The world has a great writer in Erich Maria Remarque. He is a craftsman of unquestionably first rank, a man who can bend language to his will. Whether he writes of men or of inanimate nature, his touch is sensitive, firm, and sure.”—The New York Times Book Review

Arch of Triumph

written byErich Maria Remarque

Published by Random House - 2/4/2014

The evocative story of a man without a country, Arch of Triumph is a World War II–era classic from the author of All Quiet on the Western Front. It is 1939. Despite a law banning him from performing surgery, Ravic—a German doctor and refugee living in Paris—has been treating some of the city’s most elite citizens for two years on the behalf of two less-than-skillful French physicians. Forbidden to return to his own country, and dodging the everyday dangers of jail and deportation, Ravic manages to hang on—all the while searching for the Nazi who tortured him back in Germany. And though he’s given up on the possibility of love, life has a curious way of taking a turn for the romantic, even during the worst of times. “The world has a great writer in Erich Maria Remarque. He is a craftsman of unquestionably first rank, a man who can bend language to his will. Whether he writes of men or of inanimate nature, his touch is sensitive, firm, and sure.”—The New York Times Book Review

Arch of Triumph

written byErich Maria Remarque

1/1/1945

Arch of Triumph. Translated from the German by Walter Sorell and Denver Lindley

written byErich Maria Remarque

1/1/1945

Did you know that the movie Arch of Triumph is based on the book Arch of Triumph?

In winter of 1938, Paris is crowded with refugees from the Nazis, who live in the black shadows of night, trying to evade deportation. One such is Dr. Ravic, who practices medicine illegally and stalks his old Nazi enemy Haake with murder in mind. One rainy night, Ravic meets Joan Madou, a kept woman cast adrift by her lover's sudden death. Against Ravic's better judgement, they become involved in a doomed affair; matters come to a crisis on the day war is declared.

  • Internet Movie Database:  6.3/10
